answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Dan,
I have found a few examples of longevity pay policies for various cities in Washington. For the most part, longevity pay either starts on the anniversary of employment or after a certain number of years of continuous employment.
The city of East Wenatchee, Washington has a policy that holds that longevity pay increases will be in accordance with the anniversary of an employee’s start date and will follow the pay-plan policy as established in a previous collective bargaining agreement (unless otherwise decided) This information can be seen on 20 of 66 in the pdf:
http://bit.ly/gAH5Ne 
Additionally, in Goldendale, Washington after reaching a certain step in their designated salary range they will receive monthly longevity pay (page 21-22)
http://bit.ly/hxZ8pZ
The city of Sedro-Woolley, Washington uses the term “seniority” instead of longevity, but still designates the start time to be the anniversary of employment. (page 5-6)
http://bit.ly/f9OnJb 
While the city of Renton, Washington does not have a specific pdf describing their longevity pay policy, their HR department has a very comprehensive benefits section (longevity is about ¾ of the way down the page). This city gives employees incentive pay after 5, 10, 15, and 20 years of continuous service:
http://www.rentonwa.gov/working/default.aspx?id=442#Longevity_Incentive_Pay
The city of Olympia, Washington gives longevity pay for city employees beginning after 15 years of continuous service and will be based off 2% of their salary, up to $480 per year (page 30 out of 41 of the pdf):
http://bit.ly/fT5bFA  (copy and paste the link)
I hope this helps!
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org
